Award.AwardTitle: DMUU: Center for Research on Environmental Decisions: Understanding and Improving Environmental Decisions

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This collaborative group will continue ongoing efforts to study individual and group decision making under climate uncertainty and decision making in the face of environmental risk. The researchers will focus on synthesizing theoretical and empirical results of studies conducted over the last ten years in areas such as agriculture and water management. Three themes have connected the various research projects: the presentation and use of scientific information, the role of social context across different scales, and the effects of decision architecture. The collaborative group will synthesize project results generated across different sectors, cultures, and theoretical frameworks. The focus will be on the development of products that benefit the broad academic and practitioner communities, such as a book, educational videos, and tutorials. These materials will be available to inform future studies of environmental decision goals and processes and the communication of scientific information related to environmental science in order to motivate sustainability. The collaborative group will maintain its international network of expertise and researchers through virtual connections.

The investigators will synthesize theoretical and empirical results from their prior research generated across different sectors, cultures, and theoretical frameworks and translate those results into a form accessible to other researchers. Synthesis and integration efforts of sector-based field project results (in the areas of climate, water, hazards, energy) will enable researchers to infer the influence of central constructs from cognitive and social psychology in environmental perception and decisions. Comparing findings across sectors, particularly pertaining to the description-experience gap, will allow researchers to disentangle the effect of different elements of personal experience. Synthesis activities will focus on choice architecture, where behavioral decision theories and insights are turned into interventions. A meta-analysis of the relative effectiveness of different choice architecture interventions in different domains and with different populations of decision makers will generate a matrix, including data from this collaborative group and others. This collaborative group project is supported by the NSF Directorate for Social, Behavioral, and Economic Sciences through its Decision Making Under Uncertainty (DMUU) funding opportunity.

POR.DRECONTENT:
CRED has drawn on recent research on how people make decisions and applied this research to pressing environmental issues, including climate change. This work has led to new contributions to the understanding of decision-making, to improvements in environmental and climate communication, to concrete products that support effective decision-making, and to the activities of major public and private organizations.

One important area is “framing”—the way that an issue is presented. It’s often more effective to show that climate change creates gains (opportunities for new action, whether new energy systems or new adaptation) than to emphasize losses (hazards, lower levels of resource availability). It’s also often more effective to focus on local communities as the place of action than on global scales. And it’s often more effective to combine several benefits of action (helping social groups, improving environmental conditions) rather than to address one benefit at a time. These findings bear both on large cities in developed countries (where community gardens draw support) and on rural areas in developing countries (where mountain villages reorganize their water supplies). These efforts have led to suggestions for ways to present green infrastructure projects (parks, street trees, rain gardens, etc.) to public agencies and society at large, suggesting the value of framing around co-benefits of environmental and cultural benefits, rather than around environmental benefits alone. These findings also indicate that people can be motivated to take sustainable activities when they are reminded that there will be benefits both in the present and the future, rather than in just one alone; this has supported concrete programs of organizations to draw support from older adults, who are concerned both for their own lifetimes and for future generations. In a related vein, the research shows that it can be more effective to focus on key elements of scientific information, when communicating with the public, than the full complexity—though including some details, and indicating some areas of uncertainty, are positive. This work has been used by the National Hurricane Center to improve their storm forecast products.

Another important area is “big data” and Artificial Intelligence. We apply insights from decision science to the new datasets that are available from social media, sensors, online news, internet searches, and other sources. This work shows that people are particularly responsive to communication messages about climate change in the days immediately after an unusual weather event. In a very different vein, a big data project involving georeferenced information contributed to the development of an app that has proven successful in getting people to join a bike share program and commute by bike; this is a triple win, reducing greenhouse gas emissions, improving health and improving well-being. Still underway is another project in this area: International Climate Change and Air Pollution (ICAPP) data collection project which is currently in the data collection phase. It will generate an unprecedented public dataset combining public opinion survey data, meteorological data, internet search data, social media data, and news data about climate change and air pollution across six cities. These projects join the growing literature on how behavioral interventions (e.g., invitations to participate in activities; redesigning forms such as utility bills) and messaging frames can be used to both increase citizen engagement in climate change issues and encourage sustainable action.

 These activities have led to collaborations with other fields (engineering, urban planning, architecture, water management, public health), to interdisciplinary teaching programs that link sustainability, policy, and behavioral science, and to a number of major review papers. CRED PIs have participated as lead authors for three chapters in the highly influential reports of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC)
